week3.practice3_html:
What it is

Calm Your Scalp and Body teaches you how to settle your nervous system when stress spikes, so your scalp and hair can move from â€œalarm modeâ€ into true repair.

Why this practice matters for you now

Rochelle, youâ€™re in the stabilization phaseâ€”your baby hairs show recovery is underway, but chronic stress is still pressing on the brake. This calming practice is your big domino: when your body believes itâ€™s safe again, shedding naturally slows, and those new hairs thicken. Each short reset you give your system helps lock in progress as you move toward steady regrowth by midâ€‘2025.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Notice the signs of stress (tight chest, racing thoughts, jaw clenching). The moment you catch one, pause before reacting.
  2. Place a hand over your heart or scalp and take three slow breathsâ€”inhale through your nose for 4 counts, exhale for 6. Focus on the longer exhale.
  3. Gently roll your shoulders back and loosen your facial muscles. Imagine exhaling tension out of your scalp.
  4. When strong emotion hits, step away, sip water, or stretch for 60â€¯seconds to interrupt the stress loop instead of turning to emotional eating.
  5. Commit to 2â€“3 of these microâ€‘calm breaks daily; youâ€™re retraining your stress reflex, not forcing perfection.

What to look for

  • Early wins: Easier breathing after tense moments, fewer spikes in heart rate when things go wrong, and less â€œtingleâ€ or tightness at your crown within a week or two.
  • Watch-outs: Afternoon caffeine can undo your calm. If you crave it after 3â€¯pm, swap for herbal tea or a chilled decaf latte.
  • Consistency builds momentum â€” one steady, soothed breath at a time. ğŸŒ±
